docs.snippet: Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling, who was banned for life from the National Basketball Association after a tape of his racist comments became public, claimed in a new recording he was not a bigot, according to an online report on Thursda...
docs.lead_paragraph: Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling, who was banned for life from the National Basketball Association after a tape of his racist comments became public, claimed in a new recording he was not a bigot, according to an online report on Thursday.

headline.main: Clippers Owner Sterling Denies Being Racist: Report
headline.print_headline: Clippers Owner Sterling Denies Being Racist: Report

headline.main: U.S. House Hears Witnesses Opposed to Union for College Athletes

docs.snippet: The killing of a 17-year-old German exchange student in Montana has renewed criticism of “castle doctrine” laws and exposed a cultural gulf between Germany and a gun-loving Western state....
docs.lead_paragraph: The killing of a 17-year-old German exchange student in Montana has renewed criticism of “castle doctrine” laws and exposed a cultural gulf between Germany and a gun-loving Western state.
docs.abstract: Killing of 17-year-old German exchange student Diren Dede in Missoula, Montana, has renewed criticism of 'castle doctrine' laws and exposed cultural gulf between Germany and a gun-loving American state; Markus Kaarma has been charged with deliberate homicide, but is expected to use as defense laws allowing Montana residents wider latitude to use force to defend their homes.

headline.main: In Youth’s Death, Some See a Montana Law Gone Wrong
headline.print_headline: In German Student’s Death, Some See a Law Gone Wrong in Montana
